Posts.Content: pacmom wrote: I'm hoping to continue playing during my treatment.  Has anybody been there/done that?  I'm concerned about my wig staying on!!  I see there are special baseball caps with more coverage, maybe that's the way to go? Margaret Dx 11/19/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2008 06:00AM pacmom wrote: Hi Patricia, Hope you're feeling better today.  I see that you're also posting in the Feb2008 chemo conversations -- I've joined in there too (my first treatment is on 2/12).   Just want to say that I'm sure your game will quickly get back to where you left off, so don't worry about that now!  Just do what you feel you can...
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 08:09AM pacmom wrote: Hello to all the tennis players/active gals with hair challenges, Just thought I'd report that wearing the wig while playing tennis is working great.  It never feels like it's going to go flying and doesn't get too hot.  I stopped using the tape because there was often a fake hair or two yanked out by it, and those don't grow back!  (I never tried the "It Stays" - only reg toupee tape strips.) I did buy a second identical wig so I could go somewhere after playing with a "fresh" start.  And just fyi, my wig brand is Raquel Welsh -- I can recommend it! Margaret
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 10:25AM pacmom wrote: Thanks for the replies!  I've ordered a buff and if that doesn't work I may try something from hiphat.com. 40somethingMom:  I'm still officially a 2.5, maybe playing at 3.0, so my playing will not be as strenuous.  I go to a few group tennis lessons every week which is pretty much the only time I've been able to forget about bc since my diagnosis.  Emotionally, it would be hard for me to give up, and my oncologist thought it's fine to try.  I did switch to be a sub in the spring league and will probably only play on my good weeks.  I'll try to keep you posted on how I do...  Are you starting chemo this month?
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 10:19AM pacmom wrote: CPW, Great to hear from you!  I still have about 5 days before saying bye-bye to my hair, but think I'm going to be more comfortable wearing the wig for the same reason as you.  So thanks for the tape idea.  Was it special wig-tape or just regular stuff? I'm sure Patricia will be encouraged by your message too...
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 01:02PM pacmom wrote: I'm dealing big time with this issue now, and this seems to be the most direct thread...  I've done 10 of 12 weekly Taxols.  I think around week 7 my fingernnails started hurting.  It's gotten progressively worse, painwise and about half of them are now coming off.  I have a hard time doing things like opening zip-lock bags.  I read a post a week ago about using "Bag Balm".  I found it in Walgreens and have been using it all week.  I may have started too late, or it doesn't help everyone, but it makes me feel like I'm doing something, and it really helps the cuticles!  I guess I'm just wondering how long it might take for them to fall off.   I understand the pain goes away at that point.  Also my toenails seem to be a few weeks behind -- they only hurt now, no discoloration.   I can only wear crocs!   Any help will be appreciated -- thanks!
Posts.Title: Nails falling with Taxol? formygirls pacmom

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 07:43AM pacmom wrote: Early morning greetings to my fellow February riders...  I'm learning so much reading here and know we'll all get through this chemo process... GuitarGrl -- I'm going to try without a port, even though I don't have great veins.  One less surgery (which sometimes has complications) this way.  A port can be installed between treatments if necessary.  I was told by a survivor your veins are more difficult for a year or so after, but then they go back to normal.  CookieOkie -- I'm also 3-neg.  I like nosurrender.com's take on the subject...  I have decided the dose dense isn't for me. With my family's busy schedule, I really think I have to have the 3rd week when I'm feeling close to normal.  I was told it improves my chances by about 2% -- that just doesn't seem worth it to me.  I will figure out how to send you my email address too.  Thanks, and GOOD LUCK to us all!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2008 10:11AM pacmom wrote: Hi all, Had my first treatment yesterday (2/12) and am describing it as anti-climatic.  Everything went super smooth.  Drinking lots of water and dressing warm worked wonders on getting my vein to pop up.  Wonderful nurse.  Only symptom so far is a mild dull headache which comes and goes. Kissta -- as I'm prone to medication-induced constipation, I think I'm prepared this time.  If 2 days pass w/o going, I'll take Senokot-S which is both a laxative & stool softerner.  I've got other products in the medicine cabinet, but I'm hoping staying proactive with the Senokot will be enough. Also planning to stay as physically active as possible... daily walks, circuit at gym 3x/wk, and easy tennis when I can.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 09:48PM pacmom wrote: Hi everyone, Bridget, Yes I'll be getting the Taxol weekly, starting 5/7.  A friend said to me "so you're on the downhill side!"  Boy did I need to hear that -- I was so stuck on TWELVE more -- but the downhill side -- much better! Also great to hear about the horseshow fundraiser.  Every way we turn it seems there is something going on for breast cancer awareness.  My local support group, the Bosom Buddies, is having a garage sale tomorrow and our proceeds will go towards an upcoming Relay for Life event.  I feel even better that I got rid of so much STUFF out of my house!  A win-win situation for sure. Also went to my PS this week and got the final fill in my expanders.  Now the skin and muscles will stretch for 3 months, while I'm on the Taxol. One of my sons who just got his license was in a fender bender yesterday. He says it wasn't his fault but didn't get the name, etc. of the other driver.  My dh and I have to decide what he should pay for.  Another tough life lesson....     Just got asked to sub in a tennis game on Monday --  Hope I can report back that I played decently -- wish me luck please! Hope everyone has a nice weekend -- it's starting to get hot here in Florida...
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 10:17PM pacmom wrote: Evie, I know I've seen postings saying not to get your teeth cleaned, but I asked my oncologist last time I saw him and he said I could go ahead with it.  It might be an individual thing -- maybe put a call into your doctor. Laurel, That is awesome that you ran a marathon during chemo!  Congratulations!!!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 10:08AM pacmom wrote: Hey all, I'm on the bus too.  I will receive the 1st of 4 A/C treatments on 2/12/08.  After A/C I'll have 3 months of Taxol.  Then maybe some radiation -- going for a consult on that next week.  Mostly good days and only a few bad nights.  Have 2 teenage sons and a pre-teen daughter and a husband.  Had bi-lateral mastectomies w/expanders in Nov., all is going well there, except it's a shame to have to postpone the final implant surgery until after chemo -- will just live with the baseball-breasts for the duration... So grateful for all the good advice being shared...
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 10:41AM pacmom wrote: Hi Chris, Sorry you've got an emergency scare.  Hang in.  What works pretty well for me is the serenity prayer (even tho I'm not religious).  In your case I would apply it as:  What the spot is is out of your control... What is in your control is how you deal with the waiting.  You can choose to focus on other important things that need attention right now and taking care of yourself. Hope this is a little helpful to you and that you get good news from your surgeon.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 07:08AM pacmom wrote: Good morning everyone, Just checking in.  I go for 3/12 taxol today.  The first 2 have been ok, se's not too bad overall.  I am watching the iv closely Laurel -- what a nightmare (within a nightmare) you've been through... My dh and I are taking 8 kids to a cabin on the beach this weekend.  Wish us luck!  Happy Memorial Day! Margaret

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 07:57AM pacmom wrote: I'm still here too. I've done 6 of 12 Taxols-- one week behind you... but I did Cytoxan during the first half of treatment.  And no Rads for me. Just have to finish Taxol and then have surgery to replace my expanders with final implants. I'm feeling the tiredness, but I keep pushing myself to exercise (play tennis) because it makes me feel better when I do... The weather in Michigan must be pretty nice now -- enjoy it with your beautiful grandson! Margaret

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 11:03AM pacmom wrote: Hi everyone, Had my first (1/12) Taxol yesterday and feeling 100% today - yeah!!  Hopefully that will continue...  I'm going to bring a movie to watch next week -- I wasn't prepared that the treatment would take longer than the A/C and got quite bored with the magazines, especially after reading while waiting over an hour to get into the treatment room! My daughter and I are off to Orlando tomorrow for her last volleyball tournament.  It's been a great season for her - she never rotates out, so has lots of playing time.  Here's a fill-in-the-blanks poem she did recently which I hope you'll enjoy reading  (She's 11): I hope everyone has a special weekend!

Hillary, thanks so much for reminding us that for most of us this will just be a piece of our history in no time...  Maybe I'll see you both over on the triple neg threads...

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 07:27PM pacmom wrote: Hi Nolana, I have the expanders in now and will have the 2nd surgery to replace them with implants in August, a month after my chemo ends.  There are many conversations under Breast Reconstruction which you'll find helpful I'm sure.  I think the worst things about the expanders are that they are really hard (no stomach sleeping!) and it's quite the process to get them expanded -- several trips to the doctor's office, with muscle spasms pretty much each time you get a fill up.  It seems that most are pleased with the final results, so that's something for us both to look forward too. Good luck with your treatment, hope it's not as bad as the #3.  Congrats that you're done with that anyway!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 07:44AM pacmom wrote: Hey everyone,  I'm sorry I've been out of touch with you all.  I just figured out yesterday how to have the comments to my favorite conversations forwarded to my email -- It makes it a LOT easier to check in - duh! I had my last (#4) A/C last week, so I'm halfway through, like you Bridget...  Somehow that halfway mark isn't cheering me up much though.  Maybe because I've got TWELVE Taxol's to go -- seems like so much right now... but I know 12 weeks should fly by... so I'll make it, and so will all of you!  We'll just keep putting "one foot in front of the other"... like the silly song says... I hope everyone finds lots of reasons to smile today...  Margaret
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 03:22PM pacmom wrote: Laurel, I'm not sure it's the same thing, but I had mouth sores after an A/C treatment, and the next time they had me drink ice water and suck on ice while I received the treatment.  It did the trick for me.  Something about keeping the blood vessels in the mouth constricted.  I'm going to bring some to my first Taxol next week, based on your experience...  Thanks for brightening up the pages Di with your sweet son...
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 10:50AM pacmom wrote: Hello Pam!  I'm still here too.  I guess I may be the last one to close the door -- I've got 2 more taxols to go, will finish up on 7/24.  The side effects w/Taxol is definitely cumulative.  I thought I was doing great, and then 3 weeks ago my fingernails started hurting.  It seems like I'm going to loose about 5 of the nails now.  But the worst is that now my toenails are hurting and I can't wear my tennis shoes anymore!  I refuse to give in!!!  I'm going out to buy larger/wider tennis shoes today! And I'm triple negative too -- have marked several conversations on that topic as favorites to keep up -- also you probably saw that there soon will be an "Ask-the-Expert Online Conference" on Triple-Negative Breast Cancer.  I plan to live my life like it's behind me as much as possible, but at the same time being aware of unusual body aches, etc. "that last for more than 2 weeks".    I see we were both node negative, and we've done or are doing the chemo and rads that have worked for many many other women, so we've got lots of reasons to stay positive.  All the best to all the Feb 2008 gals!
